Okay, I need to summarize this document about Red Lobster in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The document starts with Red Lobster Hospitality, LLC, an American restaurant chain based in Orlando. It mentions their operations in the US, Canada, and other countries. Then there's info about ownership changes, like being acquired by Golden Gate Capital in 2014 and Thai Union later. The key event is their 2024 bankruptcy, closing 99 restaurants, and filing for Chapter 11. They had a stalking horse agreement to sell the company. 

The history section talks about the founding in 1968, expansion, and key milestones like the Cheddar Bay Biscuits. The 2009 prototype and sale to Golden Gate Capital are important. Then there's the restructuring and bankruptcy details, including the CEO changes and the sale to RL Investor Holdings. 

Promotions section mentions the endless crab leg and shrimp deals that caused financial issues. The menu and locations are also covered, along with some pop culture references. 

So the main points are: Red Lobster's history, ownership changes, financial struggles leading to bankruptcy, and the subsequent sale and restructuring. I need to highlight the main topic, which is the company's financial issues and bankruptcy, along with key events and ownership. Also, mention the closure of locations and the sale to new investors. Keep it concise, 3-5 sentences. Avoid minor details like specific dates unless crucial. Make sure to include the bankruptcy, reasons (rents, labor costs), the sale to new investors, and the impact on locations. Also, maybe note the promotions that affected their finances. Let me structure that.

Red Lobster, a U.S.-based seafood restaurant chain founded in 1968, faced financial turmoil leading to its 2024 Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, driven by high rents, labor costs, and unprofitable promotions like the "Endless Shrimp" deal. After being acquired by Golden Gate Capital in 2014 and later fully by Thai Union, the company closed over 99 locations and entered a restructuring process, eventually selling to RL Investor Holdings in September 2024. Despite its iconic menu items and global expansion, Red Lobster's struggles highlighted challenges in sustaining profitability amid rising operational costs and shifting consumer demands.

[S1] Red Lobster


# Red Lobster



**Red Lobster Hospitality, LLC** is an American casual dining restaurant chain headquartered in Orlando, Florida. [S2] The company has operations across most of the United States and Canada, as well as in Ecuador, Japan, Mexico, and Thailand. [S3] Golden Gate Capital was Red Lobster's parent company after it was acquired from Darden Restaurants on July 28, 2014. [S4] Seafood supplier Thai Union acquired a 25 percent stake in the company in 2016 for a reported $575 million and in 2020 purchased the remaining portion from GGC. [S5] In May 2024, Red Lobster closed at least 99 of its restaurants and then filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after securing over $100 million in financing commitments from its lenders. [S6] The company has also entered a stalking horse agreement to sell itself and have its lenders manage it. [S7] ## History


### Formation and growth

The first Red Lobster restaurant was opened on January 18, 1968, in Lakeland, Florida, by entrepreneurs Bill Darden and Charley Woodsby. [S8] The oft-quoted date of March 27, 1968, is based on the incorporation date of Red Lobster Inns of America, Inc. [S9] (now GMRI, Inc.) in the Florida Secretary of State's Office. [S10] Originally billed as the "Harbor for Seafood Lovers", the first restaurant was followed by four others throughout the American South. [S11] In 1970, General Mills acquired Red Lobster as a five-unit company and with new backing, the chain expanded rapidly in the 1980s. [S12] Red Lobster entered Canada in the 1980s, in many cases by buying Ponderosa Steakhouse locations. [S13] Currently, Red Lobster generally maintains between 25 and 30 locations in Canada, the bulk in larger urban centres in Ontario (across Southern Ontario (from Southwestern Ontario through Golden Horseshoe and southern to Eastern Ontario) plus one in Sudbury, in northern Ontario and Barrie, Ontario in Central Ontario) with a smaller number in larger urban centres in all three Prairie provinces (Calgary, Edmonton, Regina, Saskatoon and Winnipeg). [S14] It exited the Quebec market (14 locations including Vanier and Montreal) in September 1997, due to financial losses, and was entirely absent from the Maritime provinces, British Columbia and the Arctic territories. [S15] In 1991, Red Lobster introduced its now famous garlic cheese biscuits (given the name Cheddar Bay Biscuits in 1996) developed by culinary leader Kurt Hankins. [S16] On March 29, 1994, Bill Darden died, after an extended illness, at the age of 75. [S17] In 1995, Red Lobster (along with Olive Garden and other sister chains), became part of Darden Restaurants, Inc. [S18] During that time, General Mills decided to release Darden into an independent, publicly traded corporation. [S19] ### 2009 prototype and sale

In 2009, Red Lobster debuted its new Bar Harbor restaurant prototype modeled after coastal New England architecture. [S20] The new exterior features include shingle and stone towers, signal flags, and Adirondack-style benches. [S21] The interior updates include dark wood paneling, warm-toned fabrics, soft lighting, and nautical decor and artwork. [S22] On December 19, 2013, Darden Restaurants announced plans to sell or spin off the Red Lobster brand, citing pressure from stock investors. [S23] This was in direct response to Darden's going over budget on a new digital platform. [S24] On May 12, 2014, Darden announced that as part of its spinoff of Red Lobster, it was converting the co-located Red Lobster and Olive Garden locations into standalone Olive Garden locations. [S25] On May 16, 2014, Darden announced it would be selling the Red Lobster seafood restaurant chain to Golden Gate Capital for US$2.1 billion. [S26] Darden announced the completion of the sale of Red Lobster on July 28, 2014. [S27] As part of the sale, a sale/leaseback of the real estate for 500 restaurants was completed to American Realty Capital Partners for $1.5 billion to finance the purchase. [S28] By 2023, rents totaled $200 million per year and was a factor in the 2024 bankruptcy filing.

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Red Lobster


# Red Lobster



**Red Lobster Hospitality, LLC** is an American casual dining restaurant chain headquartered in Orlando, Florida. [S2] The company has operations across most of the United States and Canada, as well as in Ecuador, Japan, Mexico, and Thailand. [S3] Golden Gate Capital was Red Lobster's parent company after it was acquired from Darden Restaurants on July 28, 2014. [S4] Seafood supplier Thai Union acquired a 25 percent stake in the company in 2016 for a reported $575 million and in 2020 purchased the remaining portion from GGC. [S5] In May 2024, Red Lobster closed at least 99 of its restaurants and then filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after securing over $100 million in financing commitments from its lenders. [S6] The company has also entered a stalking horse agreement to sell itself and have its lenders manage it. [S7] ## History


### Formation and growth

The first Red Lobster restaurant was opened on January 18, 1968, in Lakeland, Florida, by entrepreneurs Bill Darden and Charley Woodsby. [S8] The oft-quoted date of March 27, 1968, is based on the incorporation date of Red Lobster Inns of America, Inc. [S9] (now GMRI, Inc.) in the Florida Secretary of State's Office. [S10] Originally billed as the "Harbor for Seafood Lovers", the first restaurant was followed by four others throughout the American South. [S11] In 1970, General Mills acquired Red Lobster as a five-unit company and with new backing, the chain expanded rapidly in the 1980s. [S12] Red Lobster entered Canada in the 1980s, in many cases by buying Ponderosa Steakhouse locations. [S13] Currently, Red Lobster generally maintains between 25 and 30 locations in Canada, the bulk in larger urban centres in Ontario (across Southern Ontario (from Southwestern Ontario through Golden Horseshoe and southern to Eastern Ontario) plus one in Sudbury, in northern Ontario and Barrie, Ontario in Central Ontario) with a smaller number in larger urban centres in all three Prairie provinces (Calgary, Edmonton, Regina, Saskatoon and Winnipeg). [S14] It exited the Quebec market (14 locations including Vanier and Montreal) in September 1997, due to financial losses, and was entirely absent from the Maritime provinces, British Columbia and the Arctic territories. [S15] In 1991, Red Lobster introduced its now famous garlic cheese biscuits (given the name Cheddar Bay Biscuits in 1996) developed by culinary leader Kurt Hankins. [S16] On March 29, 1994, Bill Darden died, after an extended illness, at the age of 75. [S17] In 1995, Red Lobster (along with Olive Garden and other sister chains), became part of Darden Restaurants, Inc. [S18] During that time, General Mills decided to release Darden into an independent, publicly traded corporation. [S19] ### 2009 prototype and sale

In 2009, Red Lobster debuted its new Bar Harbor restaurant prototype modeled after coastal New England architecture. [S20] The new exterior features include shingle and stone towers, signal flags, and Adirondack-style benches. [S21] The interior updates include dark wood paneling, warm-toned fabrics, soft lighting, and nautical decor and artwork. [S22] On December 19, 2013, Darden Restaurants announced plans to sell or spin off the Red Lobster brand, citing pressure from stock investors. [S23] This was in direct response to Darden's going over budget on a new digital platform. [S24] On May 12, 2014, Darden announced that as part of its spinoff of Red Lobster, it was converting the co-located Red Lobster and Olive Garden locations into standalone Olive Garden locations. [S25] On May 16, 2014, Darden announced it would be selling the Red Lobster seafood restaurant chain to Golden Gate Capital for US$2.1 billion. [S26] Darden announced the completion of the sale of Red Lobster on July 28, 2014. [S27] As part of the sale, a sale/leaseback of the real estate for 500 restaurants was completed to American Realty Capital Partners for $1.5 billion to finance the purchase. [S28] By 2023, rents totaled $200 million per year and was a factor in the 2024 bankruptcy filing.

qa_pairs.reasoning: The question asks when Darden completed the sale of Red Lobster. Sentence [S1] explicitly states, 'Darden announced the completion of the sale of Red Lobster on July 28, 2014.' qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Darden announced the completion of the sale of Red Lobster on July 28, 2014. [S2] As part of the sale, a sale/leaseback of the real estate for 500 restaurants was completed to American Realty Capital Partners for $1.5 billion to finance the purchase. [S3] By 2023, rents totaled $200 million per year and was a factor in the 2024 bankruptcy filing. [S4] On August 6, 2014, Red Lobster announced its new headquarters location in CNL Center City Commons in Orlando. [S5] On March 6, 2015, Red Lobster officially opened the Restaurant Support Center. [S6] Seafood supplier Thai Union acquired a 25 percent stake in the company in 2016 for a reported $575 million, and in 2020 purchased the remaining portion from GGC. [S7] ### Restructuring and bankruptcy

In March 2024, Jonathan Tibus was hired as the company's new CEO. [S8] Tibus previously was CEO during the bankruptcy of Kona Grill and the chief restructuring officer of Krystal. [S9] Officials deemed Red Lobster as a "zombie brand" and said that they were exploring options to save the company, including a restructuring turnaround, fire sale, or a possible bankruptcy filing. [S10] Red Lobster also announced that it was searching for a new buyer, and if one could not be found, the company may file for bankruptcy within the coming months. [S11] On April 16, 2024, Bloomberg reported that Red Lobster was preparing to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, highlighting leases and labor costs among the issues. [S12] The company plans to exit some underperforming leases as well as address other long-term contracts and rising labor costs. [S13] The company expected to continue operating normally during the bankruptcy procedure while discussing a possible bankruptcy debt reduction plan with its creditors. [S14] On May 13, 2024, Red Lobster abruptly closed some restaurants in 28 states. [S15] This included all of its Buffalo-area locations and most of its Orlando-area locations. [S16] TAGeX Brands conducted liquidation auctions for restaurant fixtures and supplies at the closed locations and concluded them by May 16. [S17] On May 14, 2024, Red Lobster announced that it was preparing to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection before Memorial Day weekend, planning to restructure agreements with its landlords and creditors in efforts to shed some of its debt. [S18] On May 20, 2024, Red Lobster filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after securing over $100 million in financing commitments from its lenders. [S19] The company has also entered a stalking horse agreement to sell itself and have its lenders manage it, which will allow for the company to receive financing and shed some of its $1 billion debt. [S20] On May 23, 2024, Red Lobster announced that their Canadian operations would also be declaring bankruptcy by no later than May 28. [S21] The company will close some underperforming Canadian locations during the proceedings. [S22] On June 6, 2024, Red Lobster announced that if their bankruptcy plan ends up getting approved, up to 129 additional locations would be permanently shut down. [S23] One of these locations included their restaurant at Times Square in Manhattan. [S24] On June 12, hip hop rapper Flavor Flav was hired by the company to be the spokesperson of Red Lobster commercials, after he previously ordered the entire Red Lobster menu in order to save the company. [S25] In his first commercial, he would announce that CrabFest would be returning to restaurants nationwide.

[S9] Officials deemed Red Lobster as a "zombie brand" and said that they were exploring options to save the company, including a restructuring turnaround, fire sale, or a possible bankruptcy filing. [S10] Red Lobster also announced that it was searching for a new buyer, and if one could not be found, the company may file for bankruptcy within the coming months. [S11] On April 16, 2024, Bloomberg reported that Red Lobster was preparing to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, highlighting leases and labor costs among the issues. [S12] The company plans to exit some underperforming leases as well as address other long-term contracts and rising labor costs. [S13] The company expected to continue operating normally during the bankruptcy procedure while discussing a possible bankruptcy debt reduction plan with its creditors. [S14] On May 13, 2024, Red Lobster abruptly closed some restaurants in 28 states. [S15] This included all of its Buffalo-area locations and most of its Orlando-area locations. [S16] TAGeX Brands conducted liquidation auctions for restaurant fixtures and supplies at the closed locations and concluded them by May 16. [S17] On May 14, 2024, Red Lobster announced that it was preparing to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection before Memorial Day weekend, planning to restructure agreements with its landlords and creditors in efforts to shed some of its debt. [S18] On May 20, 2024, Red Lobster filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after securing over $100 million in financing commitments from its lenders. [S19] The company has also entered a stalking horse agreement to sell itself and have its lenders manage it, which will allow for the company to receive financing and shed some of its $1 billion debt. [S20] On May 23, 2024, Red Lobster announced that their Canadian operations would also be declaring bankruptcy by no later than May 28. [S21] The company will close some underperforming Canadian locations during the proceedings. [S22] On June 6, 2024, Red Lobster announced that if their bankruptcy plan ends up getting approved, up to 129 additional locations would be permanently shut down. [S23] One of these locations included their restaurant at Times Square in Manhattan. [S24] On June 12, hip hop rapper Flavor Flav was hired by the company to be the spokesperson of Red Lobster commercials, after he previously ordered the entire Red Lobster menu in order to save the company. [S25] In his first commercial, he would announce that CrabFest would be returning to restaurants nationwide.

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] One of these locations included their restaurant at Times Square in Manhattan. [S2] On June 12, hip hop rapper Flavor Flav was hired by the company to be the spokesperson of Red Lobster commercials, after he previously ordered the entire Red Lobster menu in order to save the company. [S3] In his first commercial, he would announce that CrabFest would be returning to restaurants nationwide. [S4] On June 14, it was reported that Fortress Investment Group, a Wall Street investment firm co-founded by the Milwaukee Bucks co-owner Wesley Edens, was interested in saving Red Lobster out of bankruptcy. [S5] The company evaluated which regions would fit Red Lobster's attempted comeback and revival. [S6] That same day, Red Lobster Canada announced that it would ask the Ontario court to recognize its stalking horse bid and approve a sales process as soon as next week. [S7] This procedure would allow the company to preserve their operations in Canada, as the bid would allow for lenders avoid the risk of assets being sold for a lower price. [S8] On June 18, an Ontario court approved the sale procedure for Red Lobster Canada. [S9] On August 25, 2024, Red Lobster announced the closure of 23 additional restaurants, all of which were set to be shuttered by August 31. [S10] On August 26, Damola Adamolekun was appointed CEO of Red Lobster, replacing Tibus. [S11] On September 5, 2024, a court approved Red Lobster's bankruptcy plan. [S12] RL Investor Holdings, a private group of investors consisted of TCW Private Credit, Blue Torch and funds managed by Fortress Investment Group, acquired the company after court approval on September 16. [S13] Red Lobster officially exited Chapter 11 bankruptcy that day. [S14] ## Promotions

In 2003, Red Lobster offered an endless snow crab leg promotion, the second in its history. [S15] The promotion resulted in its parent company, Darden Restaurants, taking a $3 million charge to third-quarter earnings, resulting in president Edna Morris's departure from the company. [S16] The ill-timed promotion was launched amid high wholesale crab leg prices. [S17] The chain also underestimated how many times a customer would order more. [S18] Further complicating matters at the restaurant level was the time customers spent table-side in the restaurant cracking crab legs. [S19] This resulted in increased waiting times in the lobby and overall diminished customer capacity per hour. [S20] Red Lobster introduced a new Daily Deals menu in 2020, featuring Endless Shrimp Mondays and more deals. [S21] In June 2023, Red Lobster reintroduced Ultimate Endless Shrimp, normally run as a limited-time promotion during autumn, as a permanent addition to their menu. [S22] For $20, guests could order two shrimp dishes to start, and keep ordering until they were full. [S23] This resulted in a $11 million loss for Red Lobster in its third quarter earnings for that year, as the company underestimated the amount of customers taking advantage of a deal that had low profit margins. [S24] In response, Red Lobster raised the prices on the deal twice, from $20 to $22, and then to $25. [S25] ## Menu

The brand specializes in seafood, including crab, fish, lobster, mollusks, and shrimp. [S26] It also serves chicken, desserts, pasta, and steak. ? [S27] ### Lobster bisque controversy

In February 2016, *Inside Edition* reported that Red Lobster used a mix of less expensive langostino along with Maine lobster in its lobster bisque recipe. [S28] ## Locations

As of February 13, 2025, the company had 514 locations worldwide. [S29] These locations span 44 US states, Canada, Ecuador, Japan, Mexico, and Thailand. [S30] ## In popular culture

In 2007, writer Stewart O'Nan published the novella *Last Night at the Lobster* about the closing of a Red Lobster restaurant in Connecticut. [S31] In February 2016, singer Beyonc referenced Red Lobster in her single "Formation". [S32] After unexpectedly releasing the single and performing it during the Super Bowl 50 halftime show, Red Lobster reported a 33% sales increase.
